subanswer.text: Jim's income increased during college because of his degree, but it also decreased due to not working. Let's say Jim got paid $25,000 annually before college. So we know that the difference between his pre-college income and his post-college income is equal to the cost of tuition (which equals the amount of student loans he obtained) plus whatever interest he had to pay on those loans. In the second year, he would owe $50,000 in interest and another $50,000 for tuition, making the total $100,000. This goes on until year 4 when he has finished paying off his tuition, but still has to pay interest on the remaining balance of $150,000 (after paying off the last year's tuition). Since we don't know exactly when Jim started earning money from his degree, let's assume it's the beginning of the fourth year (immediately after graduation). This gives us an extra $75,000 of income for year 4. Using our equation above, we can find out how much he lost during college (since his income during college was less than his pre-college income): Post-graduation income - (Pre-college income + Cost of College) = Pre-college income
